perturbation.original_text: Intuit will maintain accurate records with respect to the calculation of Impressions delivered pursuant to this Agreement. Client may, upon no less than thirty (30) days prior written notice to Intuit, cause an independent Certified Public Accountant to inspect all relevant records of Intuit upon which the calculation of Impressions under the Usage Reports are based during Client's normal business hours.
perturbation.changed_text: Intuit will endeavor to maintain records with respect to the calculation of Impressions delivered pursuant to this Agreement. Client may, with reasonable notice to Intuit, request an inspection of relevant records of Intuit upon which the calculation of Impressions under the Usage Reports are based during mutually convenient business hours.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates 'accurate records,' whereas the modified version weakens this obligation by stating Intuit will 'endeavor to maintain records.' Additionally, 'no less than thirty (30) days prior written notice' is replaced with 'reasonable notice', and 'Client's normal business hours' is changed to 'mutually convenient business hours,' introducing ambiguity about the timing and scope of the audit. This contradicts generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) which requires businesses to maintain comprehensive accounting records.

perturbation.original_text: Throughout the Term Intuit will not place, and will not allow any party acting on its behalf to place, any graphic, link or other form of advertising or media on any page of the Quicken.com Site and/or on any page on the AOL.com Personal Finance Site (other than the Channel Home Page), which markets or promotes any electronic postage product, postage meter and/or service ("Postage Products") offered by a Client Competitor.
perturbation.changed_text: Throughout the Term Intuit will try to avoid placing, and will discourage any party acting on its behalf from placing, any graphic, link or other form of advertising or media on any page of the Quicken.com Site and/or on any page on the AOL.com Personal Finance Site (other than the Channel Home Page), which directly markets or promotes any electronic postage product, postage meter and/or service ("Postage Products") offered by a Client Competitor.
perturbation.explanation: The original text is a strict prohibition, while the modified version uses phrases like 'try to avoid' and 'discourage', weakening the obligation. Adding 'directly' also creates a loophole, allowing for indirect promotion of competitors. This introduces ambiguity and might conflict with the spirit, if not the letter, of the exclusivity agreement, potentially harming the client. This may run afoul of California's Unfair Competition Law (Business and Professions Code Section 17200 et seq.) if it allows Intuit to unfairly compete with Stamps.com.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California's Unfair Competition Law (Business and Professions Code Section 17200 et seq.)

perturbation.original_text: Client will defend and/or settle any third party claim brought against Intuit, its affiliates, officers, directors, employees, consultants and agents arising from: (1) a breach of Client's representations or warranties under Section 16.1; (2) any claim that Client's Impression Materials infringe or violate any third party's copyright, U.S. patent, trade secret, any patent outside of the US which Client has knowledge of, or trademark; or (3) content provided by Client for the Client Site or the products and services of Client offered on the Client Site, and will pay resulting costs, damages and reasonable attorneys' fees finally awarded, provided that Intuit promptly notified Client in writing of any and all such claims.
perturbation.changed_text: Client will consider defending and/or settling any third party claim brought against Intuit, its affiliates, officers, directors, employees, consultants and agents arising from: (1) a potential breach of Client's representations or warranties under Section 16.1; (2) any claim that Client's Impression Materials arguably infringe or violate any third party's copyright, U.S. patent, trade secret, any patent outside of the US which Client has knowledge of, or trademark; or (3) content provided by Client for the Client Site or the products and services of Client offered on the Client Site, and will cover what Client considers to be reasonable costs, damages and reasonable attorneys' fees, provided that Intuit provides timely notification to Client in writing regarding any such claim.
perturbation.explanation: The original text imposes a clear duty to defend and indemnify, while the modified version introduces uncertainty with phrases like 'will consider defending,' 'potential breach,' 'arguably infringe,' and 'what Client considers to be reasonable costs'. This makes the obligation subjective and dependent on Client's interpretation, potentially leaving Intuit vulnerable. This is potentially non-compliant with basic principles of contract law, where a party is expected to honor the agreement.
